text: [Music]
there's there's small things I can think
of straight off the bat um but for
instance I I remember growing up and my
mother always saying never cut your
fingernails after
dark and uh I I to this day probably
have never cut my fingernails after Dark
and I thought about it and I I I
researched this a little bit it doesn't
appear in my novel but I was interested
in why why on Earth do a lot of Iranians
think that you can't cut your
fingernails after dark and the origin I
believe of of this Superstition is it
was in a the the era pre-
electricity you know people would
actually get hurt you know utilizing
scissors and cutting their you know
fingernails or toenails or whatever uh
in the in the dark or with kerosene
lamps or whatever they used I don't I
don't know but it it seemed to me that
that was the reason um and and I I love
that I love that sort of
folklore um but there's tons of stuff
like that I mean I grew up as a child
completely neurotic because of all these
things my parents would tell me the
ancient cultural um Voodoo that was
always sort of present in our household
um and it made me very very stressed out
as a child how do you merge that with
sort of modern living and trying to um
assimilate to this new world that you're
in um was very difficult for me you know
I was very um cognizant of learning
English in in the
US and uh it was it was very harrowing
for me because I was always trying to
sort of fit in and do it fast before
anyone can notice the difference um but
you know the minute someone kids would
meet my parents you know the minute they
entered the picture it would seem like
they would just
unravel my whole um my whole guise in a
bit bit um so I was always a little bit
at odds with them and I think that that
is definitely explored ad nauseum in the
book
